0.text:
Vehicle Telematics
 Technologies for real-time vehicle tracking, diagnostics, driver behavior monitoring, and location-based services.

1.text:
Infotainment Technologies
 In-car entertainment, connectivity, and user interface innovations for improved driver and passenger experience.

2.text:
Fleet Management Solutions
 Platforms and tools that support operational efficiency, route optimization, maintenance, and vehicle tracking at scale.

3.text:
Logistics & Last-Mile Technologies
 Smart solutions for delivery logistics, routing, and optimization — with a focus on first/last-mile challenges.

4.text:
Insurance Technologies (InsurTech)
 Usage-based insurance, risk modeling, and connected vehicle data applications in insurance innovation.

5.text:
Vehicle Safety Technologies
 Advanced safety systems, including collision prevention, driver assistance, and situational awareness enhancements.

6.text:
Electrification
 Technologies supporting the shift to electric vehicles, particularly in areas related to charging infrastructure and energy optimization.

7.text:
Third-Party Telematics Integration
 Opportunities and platforms that enable external developers or partners to build and deploy services on top of telematics data infrastructure.

8.text:
Cybersecurity for Connected Vehicles and Machines (Lower Priority)
 Interest in startups securing automotive or industrial systems.
 Example benchmark: Upstream Security.

9.text:
Lifecycle Management Systems (High Priority)
 Technologies that support full-cycle customer engagement — from purchase through upgrades, performance monitoring, and service ("cradle to grave").

10.text:
Predictive Machine Health & Maintenance (High Priority)
 Advanced sensing (vibration, acoustics, fluid analysis, etc.) combined with intelligent data processing to detect early machine faults and performance degradation.

11.text:
Manufacturing Process Insights & Quality Control (Lower Priority)
 Startups that offer advanced manufacturing optimization tools, including real-time quality assurance and production analytics.

12.text:
Autonomous System Development Tools (High Priority)
 “Picks and shovels” for autonomy: simulation platforms, virtual validation tools, synthetic data generation, and AI for autonomous decision-making.

13.text:
Low-Cost Connectivity in GNSS-Denied Environments (Medium–High Priority)
 Innovative sensing or connectivity technologies enabling operations where GPS fails — e.g., under tree canopy in vineyards or orchards.

14.text:
Unique Low-Cost Sensor Technologies for Environmental Perception (High Priority)
 New sensing modalities for soil, crop, field boundary, and machine status awareness — to drive operational efficiency and sustainability for farmers.

15.text:
Mobility as a Service (MaaS)
 Technologies and platforms that deliver transportation as an integrated service.

16.text:
Telematics Systems
 Example systems: THOREB and Traffilog. Used for remote monitoring, diagnostics, and real-time fleet data tracking.

17.text:
Electric Ecosystem Optimization
 Includes EV charging management, battery optimization, and other electric system improvements.

18.text:
Garage Operations
 Preventive maintenance, employee productivity, full timeline tracking of a bus's stay (entry to exit), and data accessibility/analytics.

19.text:
Trip Optimization (Not Limited to Public Transit)
 Algorithms or platforms that improve travel efficiency beyond just public transportation.

20.text:
Transportation-Specific CRM
 CRM systems for transportation orgs, supporting safety officers, HR, and more.

21.text:
Ridership Promotion
 Customer-focused initiatives and technologies to increase public transport usage.

22.text:
V2X – Vehicle-to-Everything Communication
 Real-time wireless data exchange between vehicles and infrastructure, tied to smart city tech.

23.text:
IoT Solutions for Transportation
 Covers ticketing, fleet management, user identification, and big data applications.

24.text:
Garage Digitalization and Workflow Automation
 Tech to automate and digitize work processes in garages, including queue management.

25.text:
Power Outage Protection
 Solutions that protect sensitive tech (e.g., ISR controllers) from electrical disruptions.

26.text:
Cybersecurity for Onboard Systems
 Cyber protection for ticketing machines, controllers, and other bus tech.

27.text:
GPS Signal Retention
 Preventing or mitigating the loss of GPS signals in buses.

28.text:
Bus Accident Detection & Attribution
 Systems that detect accidents and determine driver responsibility.

29.text:
EV Energy Monitoring
 Tools to measure and manage electricity usage in electric buses.

30.text:
Battery Life Extension
 Technologies aimed at prolonging the operational life of electric vehicle batteries.

31.text:
System Fault Detection and Alerting
 Identifying systemic faults in buses and issuing immediate alerts.

32.text:
Public Transport Line Optimization
 Tools and methods for optimizing the efficiency and planning of transit routes.

33.text:
Ticketing System Reliability
 Solutions for ticketing-related communication and hardware issues.

34.text:
Driver Behavior Monitoring
 Systems that evaluate and improve driving habits for safety and efficiency.

36.text:
Solid-State Batteries
 Development and application of next-generation solid-state battery technologies.

37.text:
Battery Capacity & Production
 Improving energy density and scaling manufacturing of EV batteries.

38.text:
EV Weight Reduction
 Technologies aimed at reducing vehicle weight to enhance efficiency and performance.

39.text:
Mobility Resource Circulation
 Solutions promoting reuse and recycling in mobility systems; enabling circular economy in transportation.

40.text:
Human-Machine Interface (HMI)
 Enhancing interaction between humans and vehicles; understanding human behavior to improve system design.

41.text:
Automatic Production
 Advanced robotics and automation in vehicle manufacturing.
 Example startup: CIVAN Lasers.

42.text:
Wireless Energy Transmission
 Wireless power technologies — from terrestrial to space-based systems.
 Example startup: Nt-Tao.

43.text:
Renewable Energy Generation & Usage
 Leveraging hydrogen and carbon-based energy carriers for clean power generation.
 Example startup: Nugen.

44.text:
Advanced Power Materials
 High-frequency and high-voltage power materials for next-gen systems.

45.text:
Thermal Management / Heat Sink
 Technologies that optimize thermal regulation in high-performance environments.

46.text:
Logic Systems
 Novel SoC (System-on-Chip) designs, structures, and manufacturing processes.

47.text:
Metal Magnets
 Materials innovation for efficient magnetic components, focusing on reduced mining and recyclability.
 Example startups: Fornax, Boson Energy.

48.text:
Queue Management & Customer Experience (New – April 2025)
 Technologies to minimize queues at EV charging hubs, or to make waiting time more engaging and productive for drivers.

49.text:
Cybersecurity for EV Charging Infrastructure
 Broad interest in cybersecurity — especially for charging stations, not vehicles. Includes software and network protection for EV hubs.

50.text:
Plug and Charge (ISO 15118)
 Integration and optimization of the ISO 15118 plug-and-charge standard. Interest in using it to offer seamless, value-added services for EV drivers.

51.text:
Smart Payment Solutions
 App-based and in-vehicle payment solutions for EV charging, especially from regions outside Europe (e.g., Asia). Focus on innovations that go beyond credit cards.

52.text:
Predictive Maintenance for Chargers
 Systems that can forecast charger malfunctions or downtime to reduce onsite maintenance and improve uptime.

53.text:
Dynamic Pricing for EV Charging
 Price optimization technologies that adjust charging rates based on time of day, demand, or external conditions.

54.text:
Electricity Storage at Charging Hubs
 Grid-independent power storage solutions for high-demand sites, plus additional services enabled by onsite energy storage.

55.text:
Battery Life & State of Health (SOH) Optimization
 Tools that help customers charge efficiently, reduce battery degradation, and understand their battery health status.

56.text:
Foresight & Disruptive Market Trends
 Open to disruptive technologies or market shifts that Drive TLV believes should be on their radar — broad and future-focused.

57.text:
Electrification Technologies
 Solutions that support the transition to electric vehicles, including drivetrain innovation, fleet electrification strategies, and energy efficiency improvements.

58.text:
Digital Customer Experience
 Tools and platforms that enhance the digital interaction of customers throughout the rental journey — including booking, onboarding, personalization, and self-service.

59.text:
EV Charging Solutions
 Technologies for deploying, optimizing, and managing EV charging infrastructure, especially at scale for fleet operations.

60.text:
Logistics Technology
 Smart solutions to improve vehicle logistics, fleet operations, routing, delivery, and turnaround management.

61.text:
Gamification & Behavioral Nudging for Sustainable Mobility
 Platforms that influence user mobility behavior through gamification, loyalty programs, or nudging — with the goal of reducing CO₂ emissions.
 Example: Ummadum.
 Prioritize: Open to a wide variety of solutions in this space.

62.text:
Bioethanol (E85) Solutions
 Startups working with or innovating around E85 (Bioethanol fuel).
 Note: No urgent need unless a highly visionary/outstanding solution is identified.
 Mentioned in context of existing work with StepOne.

63.text:
Mitigating Electrification Impact on Leasers
 Solutions addressing negative side effects of fleet electrification for leasing customers.
 Example: Startups issuing voluntary carbon credits to support transition from Internal Combustion Engines (ICE) to Battery Electric Vehicles (BEV).

64.text:
End-of-Life Recycling (Aluminum Focus)
 Technologies that enable recycling of post-manufacturing and post-consumer aluminum products.

65.text:
Metal Recycling & Sorting Technology
 Advanced systems that separate aluminum from mixed materials using novel sorting techniques.

66.text:
Metal Purification
 Processes that enhance the quality of recycled aluminum during the melt or recovery phase.

67.text:
Beverage Packaging Recycling
 Solutions focused on recycling used aluminum beverage cans (UBCs).

68.text:
Circularity Enablers
 Technologies that drive circular economy models — e.g., traceability, reuse, lifecycle optimization.

69.text: B. Aluminum Market Support & Material Innovation

70.text:
Aluminum Stamping and Forming
 New approaches for forming flat-rolled aluminum into usable structures efficiently and sustainably.

71.text:
Battery Enclosure Technology (Aluminum-Based)
 Innovations using aluminum in EV battery enclosures for thermal management, safety, and weight optimization.

72.text:
Active Coatings
 Coatings that enhance surface properties of aluminum — such as corrosion resistance or conductivity.

73.text:
Product Design for Recycling
 Designing aluminum-based products with recycling and material recovery in mind.

74.text:
Waste Heat Utilization
 Energy recovery systems that convert process heat into usable power or reduce emissions.

75.text:
Energy Management
 Technologies aimed at reducing industrial energy consumption during production and processing.

76.text:
Advanced Renewables
 Renewable energy technologies supporting sustainable operations (excluding geothermal; solar and wind preferred).

77.text:
Autonomous Driving & Radar Systems
 Technologies that enable autonomous vehicle perception, decision-making, and control, including radar-based sensing solutions.

78.text:
Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs)
 Platforms or components supporting robotic autonomy in industrial, logistics, or mobility environments.

79.text:
AI-Enabled Use Cases in Automotive (Beyond ADAS & IVI)
 Applications of AI in the vehicle that go beyond advanced driver assistance and infotainment — such as predictive maintenance, personalization, or in-cabin sensing.

80.text:
Software-Defined Vehicle (SDV) Infrastructure
 Tools and technologies for in-vehicle data collection, data fusion, and compute architectures that enable SDV development.

81.category:
Core Strategy:
 Goodyear Ventures is focused on identifying more sustainable materials for tires and better uses for end-of-life tires (ELTs). Their interest areas fall into four main categories:

82.category:
Core Strategy:
 Goodyear Ventures is focused on identifying more sustainable materials for tires and better uses for end-of-life tires (ELTs). Their interest areas fall into four main categories:
82.text:
High-Value Reuse (Non-Tire)
 Innovative uses for tire-derived or recycled materials in non-tire applications.

83.category:
Core Strategy:
 Goodyear Ventures is focused on identifying more sustainable materials for tires and better uses for end-of-life tires (ELTs). Their interest areas fall into four main categories:
83.text:
High-Value Reuse in Construction
 Using end-of-life tire materials in construction-related applications.

84.text:
Circular Sources (Non-Tire)
 Solutions that contribute to a circular economy using non-tire feedstocks.

85.text:
Bio-Based Materials
 Broad interest in replacing petroleum-based inputs with renewable, biological alternatives.

86.text:
Soy Oil
 Use of soy-derived oil as a renewable rubber ingredient.

87.text:
Bio-Isoprene
 Sourcing isoprene from renewable biological processes.

88.category:
Bio-Butadiene
 Renewable alternatives to petroleum-based butadiene.
88.text:
Methane-Derived Butadiene
 Converting methane into butadiene as a lower-impact synthetic route.

89.category:
Bio-Butadiene
 Renewable alternatives to petroleum-based butadiene.
89.text:
Circular Butadiene (from Tire-Derived Naphtha)
 Extracting and reusing butadiene from processed end-of-life tires.

90.text:
Devulcanization Technologies
 Breaking down vulcanized rubber for reuse in new tire compounds.

91.text:
Plant Waste Rubber Recycling
 Recycling rubber sourced from agricultural or plant-based waste streams.

92.text:
Advanced Recovered Carbon Black (rCB)
 High-purity rCB solutions recovered from tire pyrolysis or other ELT recycling methods.

93.text:
ELT-Derived Circular Resins
 Polymers and resins created from chemically processed ELT materials.

94.text:
Lower Carbon Technologies (General)
 Startups with a carbon-reducing approach across the tire material value chain.

95.text:
Recycled PET
 Use of post-consumer polyethylene terephthalate (e.g., from plastic bottles) in tire materials.

96.text:
RHA Silica (Rice Husk Ash Silica)
 Silica produced from agricultural waste (rice husks), a lower-emission alternative.

97.text:
CO₂-Derived Carbon Black
 Producing carbon black from captured CO₂ instead of fossil fuels.

98.text:
Fast Charging – Hardware & Software Solutions
 Innovations that enable faster, more efficient electric vehicle charging across hardware and software layers.

99.text:
Power Electronics
 Circuit and system designs that improve energy conversion, distribution, and efficiency in EV propulsion systems.

100.text:
Circularity in Propulsion & Energy
 Business models and technologies that promote reuse, recycling, and sustainable practices in propulsion and energy systems.

101.text:
HVAC & Heat Pump Systems
 Efficient in-vehicle heating and cooling technologies, including heat pumps and thermal management systems.

102.text:
In-Cabin Technologies (e.g., AR HUDs)
 Enhanced user experience systems such as Augmented Reality Heads-Up Displays (AR HUDs) and smart interior tech.

103.text:
In-Car Payments & Parking Aggregators
 Digital services enabling seamless in-car transactions — including charging payments, tolls, parking, and more.

104.text:
Smart Surface Materials
 Advanced materials with interactive or responsive properties, improving functionality or aesthetics inside and outside the car.

105.text:
Generative AI for Automotive Applications
 Use of GenAI in design, personalization, driver interaction, or engineering automation within the automotive domain.

106.text:
Semiconductor & Compute Technologies
 Innovations in SoC design, simulation, chip development, and cost-effective MCU architectures (e.g., RISC-V).

107.text: Tools and models that forecast events or behaviors using data—such as predicting maintenance needs, optimizing fleet usage, or anticipating road incidents.

108.text: Technologies that reduce or eliminate reliance on paper documentation—for example, digital forms, electronic invoicing, or cloud-based workflow systems.

109.text: Solutions that help determine and manage the most efficient transportation option for a given scenario—could include dynamic route selection, multimodal trip planning, or fleet dispatch optimization.

110.text: Unified platforms for vehicle-related payments such as fuel, EV charging, tolls, maintenance, accident repairs, and more. This includes controlled systems for collecting payments (e.g., traffic violations, insurance deductibles) or issuing them (e.g., driver reimbursements). There's a strong interest in consolidating currently fragmented payment tools.
